did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: The Oakton High School Collection spans the years 1928-1997 and consists of three issues of the school newsletter “Oak Leaves”, a reunion program, and a high school diploma.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Oakton High School Collection, MSS 11-12, Virginia Room, Fairfax County Public Library

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Donated by Mayo S. Stuntz on May 20, 1997

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p:

EAD generated by Ross Landis, 2018

bioghist.head: Historical and Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Oakton High School traces its roots to 1911, when a one year course was offered in Sutton’s Store in Oakton, Virginia. In 1913, the school officially became known as “Oakton High School” when a two year course was offered, making it the first high school in the Providence District. In 1914, a new two-story frame school building was constructed at the corner of Chain Bridge Road and Blake Lane. This building was used until 1935 when Oakton High School was decommissioned after the new Fairfax High School opened. The old high school building was used as an elementary school until it mysteriously burned down in January 1944. A new Oakton High School was built in 1967 on Sutton Road, and in 2017 the school celebrated its 50th anniversary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Oakton High School Collection spans the years 1928-1997 and consists of three issues of the school newsletter “Oak Leaves”, a reunion program, and a high school diploma. The diploma was awarded to Hazel Catherine Showalter (Sebodee) and signed by M.D. Hall, F.B. Cunningham, Dr. F.M. Brooks, and Wilbert Woodson. Subjects include Oakton High School and education in Fairfax County, Virginia.
